Personal Observation
-3
Supplemental income would be sought from foundations and
project activities, but these funds would be add-ons and
would not be counted on for basic support.
The Fellows memo was given sufficient endorsement by staff
to warrant a special staff task force which is now developing
a paper on costs, staffing, services, market potential, etc.
for early staff attention.
Finally, I suggest we look upon the current situation as a
way of making a virtue out of adversity. Let us move forward
to seize this opportunity to accelerate moves that might
otherwise have failed or taken decades to accomplish through
evolutionary processes:
1. The development of a new unified structure to
represent the broadcast licensees, exploiting
the power potential of lay board members and,
2. the development of a companion organization
serving the professional needs of all elements
in the field and fostering the public
telecommunications concept for the future.
It is appropriate to examine the whole range of emerging
possibilities and not act with precipitate haste. We
need to trace out and assess the impact of new approaches
on related activities in order to predict how effective
the new set of interacting elements will perform.
It is also wise not to break completely or even substantially
with the past, but to rectify weaknesses and build upon
present strengths. It is non-pragmatic to believe that a
totally new system can spring forth full-grown and be
capable of meeting all our needs. Educational institutions
are more evolutionary than they are revolutionary.
NAEB has demonstrated in the past that it is fully capable
of generating modifications that are constructively
responsive to altered circumstances and reflect our
awareness of changing necessities. Nor should we take the
easy or most expedient way.
What we must do is to act, rather than merely react, and
exert the power of creativity that shapes a system to fit
the times and need.
3/15/73
. -WGH
